{{Infobox MLB player |name=Rick Reuschel |image=Rick Reuschel 1981.JPG |position=[[Pitcher]] |bats=Right |throws=Right |birth_date={{Birth date and age|1949|5|16}} |birth_place=[[Quincy, Illinois]] |debutdate=June 19 |debutyear=1972 |debutteam=Chicago Cubs |finaldate=April 22 |finalyear=1991 |finalteam=San Francisco Giants |stat1label=[[Winâloss record (pitching)|WinâLoss record]] |stat1value=214â191 |stat2label=[[Earned run average]] |stat2value=3.37 |stat3label=[[Strikeouts]] |stat3value=2,015 |teams= * [[Chicago Cubs]] ({{By|1972}}â{{By|1981}}) * [[New York Yankees]] ({{By|1981}}) * [[Chicago Cubs]] ({{By|1983}}â{{By|1984}}) * [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] ({{By|1985}}â{{By|1987}}) * [[San Francisco Giants]] ({{By|1987}}â{{By|1991}}) |highlights= * 3Ã [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|All-Star]] selection ([[1977 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1977]], [[1987 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1987]], [[1989 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1989]]) * 2Ã [[Gold Glove Award]] winner (1985, 1987) * 1985 [[Hutch Award]] * 1985 [[The Sporting News Comeback Player of the Year Award|NL Comeback Player of the Year]] }} '''Rickey Eugene Reuschel''' (pronounced RUSH-el) (born May 16, 1949 in [[Quincy, Illinois]]) is a former [[Professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] [[pitcher]] from the early 1970s into the early 1990s.[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/r/reuscri01.shtml?redir Rick Reuschel at Baseball Reference][http://www.thebaseballcube.com/players/R/Rick-Reuschel.shtml Rick Reuschel at The Baseball Cube] His nickname was "''Big Daddy''" because of his portly physique.[http://www.thebaseballpage.com/players/reuscri01.php Rick Reuschel at The Baseball Page] He was known for his deceptive style of pitching, which kept [[hitter]]s off balance by constantly varying the speeds of his pitches.[http://books.google.com/books?id=sjQDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA77&dq=baseball+digest+rick+reuschel#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20rick%20reuschel&f=false ''Rick Reuschel: He Lets Batter Get Himself Out'' by Casey Tefertiller, Baseball Digest, December 1988, Vol. 47, No. 12, ISSN 0005-609X] ==Major League career== Reuschel was listed as 6-foot-4 and 225 pounds, which made him a few pounds heavier than his franchise-mate from two generations earlier, [[Hippo Vaughn]]. Reuschel could run surprisingly well for his size (logging 4 triples in his batting career) and he was frequently used as a pinch runner on days he was not pitching. He was also a fair - though awkward-looking - hitter, batting well over .200 several times. His older brother [[Paul Reuschel]] also pitched for the Cubs for a few years while Reuschel was pitching, but was not nearly as effective as his younger brother and his career was much shorter.[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/r/reuscpa01.shtml Paul Reuschel at Baseball Reference] Both of them were Illinois farm boys, with strong physiques and plain-spoken ways. The two are the only siblings to combine on a [[shutout]]. On August 21, [[1975 Chicago Cubs season|1975]], Rick started and went 6{{frac|1|3}} [[Inning (baseball)|innings]] against the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]], followed by Paul, who pitched the final 2{{frac|2|3}} innings for the Cubs' 7-0 win.[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/CHN/CHN197508210.shtml August 21, 1975 Dodgers-Cubs box score at Baseball Reference] Reuschel began his [[Major League Baseball]] career when he was drafted in the third round of the [[1970 Major League Baseball Draft]] by the [[Chicago Cubs]],[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=reuscri01 Rick Reuschel Trades and Transactions at Baseball Almanac] at a time when they were declining in the post-[[Leo Durocher|Durocher]] era, and provided a strong arm for the Cubs' increasingly mediocre staff. After spending two years in the [[Minor League baseball|minor leagues]], he joined the Cubs' major league team in [[1972 Chicago Cubs season|1972]]. His best season was in [[1977 Chicago Cubs season|1977]], when the Cubs made a brief run at the [[Pennant (sports)|pennant]]. Reuschel won 20 games and finished third in the [[Cy Young Award]] voting behind [[Steve Carlton]] and [[Tommy John]].[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1977.shtml#NLcya 1977 National League Cy Young Award voting results at Baseball Reference] In addition, Reuschel pitched in a memorable game for Cub fans on July 28, 1977, when making a rare relief appearance on two days rest, he entered the 13th inning of a 15-15 tie between the Cubs and the [[Cincinnati Reds]] at [[Wrigley Field]]. Reuschel retired two batters to end the top of the 13th. Then, he singled and scored the game-winning run in the bottom of the 13th, also picking up the victory in the 16-15 contest.[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/CHN/CHN197707280.shtml July 28, 1977 Reds-Cubs box score at Baseball Reference] Reuschel was traded to the [[New York Yankees]] in [[1981 New York Yankees season|1981]]. That year, Reuschel made his first [[World Series]] appearances.[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1981_WS.shtml 1981 World Series at Baseball Reference] The [[1981 World Series]] marked the last chapter of the Dodgers-Yankees trilogy of that era, this one won by the Dodgers. Reuschel was ineffective in that Series, and it appeared his career might be finished. He returned to the Cubs and was on the roster in [[1984 Chicago Cubs season|1984]] when they won the [[National League Eastern Division]] and made the playoffs,[http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/CHC/1984.shtml 1984 Chicago Cubs Batting, Pitching, & Fielding Statistics at Baseball Reference] but, somewhat controversially, he was not named to the playoff roster. Reuschel was signed by the [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] in [[1985 Pittsburgh Pirates season|1985]] as a [[free agent]], and had a 14-8 won-loss record with the last-place Pirates, earning him the National League's [[The Sporting News Comeback Player of the Year Award|Comeback Player of the Year]] award.[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/awards/comeback_player_of_the_year_award.shtml The Comeback Player of the Year Award at Baseball Almanac][http://books.google.com/books?id=qTQDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA34&dq=baseball+digest+rick+reuschel#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20rick%20reuschel&f=false ''How Perseverence Paid Off for Rick Reuschel'' by Al Doyle, Baseball Digest, May 1986, Vol. 45, No. 5, ISSN 0005-609X] The Pirates traded Reuschel to the [[San Francisco Giants]] in late [[1987 Pittsburgh Pirates season|1987]] for [[Jeff Robinson (relief pitcher)|Jeff Robinson]] and [[Scott Medvin]]. Reuschel, finally back with a contender, became the ace of the Giants' staff and helped them make a late run to the National League Western Division title, their first division title since [[1971 San Francisco Giants season|1971]]. He followed that season by winning 19 games for the Giants in 1988. In [[1989 San Francisco Giants season|1989]], Reuschel won 17 games for the Giants as he helped lead them to the [[1989 World Series|World Series]] (their first since [[1962 World Series|1962]]).[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1989_WS.shtml 1989 World Series at Baseball Reference] In the [[1989 World Series]], Reuschel was the losing pitcher in Game 2 with an 11.25 [[earned run average|ERA]], five earned runs, and five hits given up against the [[Oakland Athletics]].[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/OAK/OAK198910150.shtml 1989 World Series Game 2 box score at Baseball Reference] In [[1989 in baseball|1989]] at the age of 40, Reuschel was selected as the starting pitcher for the National League in the [[1989 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1989 All-Star Game]], and gave up a lead off [[home run]] to [[Bo Jackson]], followed by [[Wade Boggs]]' home run to start the game.[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/ALS/ALS198907110.shtml 1989 Major League All-Star game box score at Baseball Reference] ==Career statistics== In a 19-year career, Reuschel compiled a record of 214-191 in 557 games (529 starts). He had 102 career [[complete game]]s and 26 of those were [[shutout]]s. He allowed 1330 [[earned run]]s and 2015 [[strike out]]s in 3548 and 1/3 [[innings pitched]]. Reuschel was a two-time [[Gold Glove Award]] winner and a three-time All-Star.[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/gold_glove_nl.shtml#multi National League Gold Glove Award winners at Baseball Reference] As of [[2009 in baseball|2009]], Reuschel was is in the [[Top 100 winning pitchers of all time]]. Reuschel won the [[Hutch Award]] in [[1985 in sports|1985]],[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/hutch_gehrig_ruth_clemente.shtml Hutch Award winners at Baseball Reference] and was also a winner of [[The Sporting News Comeback Player of the Year Award]]. Reuschel was named to the [[Baseball Digest]] 1972 Rookie All-Star team.[http://books.google.com/books?id=YTQDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA30&dq=baseball+digest+rick+reuschel#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20rick%20reuschel&f=false Baseball Digest, December 1989] ==See also== *[[List of Major League Baseball leaders in career wins]] *[[MLB All-Time Hit Batsmen List]] *[[Top 100 strikeout pitchers of all time]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Baseballstats|br=r/reuscri01 |fangraphs=1010852 |cube=rick-reuschel}} *[http://books.google.com/books?id=qTQDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA34&dq=baseball+digest+rick+reuschel#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20rick%20reuschel&f=false ''How Perseverence Paid Off for Rick Reuschel'' by Al Doyle, Baseball Digest, May 1986] *[http://books.google.com/books?id=sjQDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA77&dq=baseball+digest+rick+reuschel#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20rick%20reuschel&f=false ''Rick Reuschel: He Lets Batter Get Himself Out'' by Casey Tefertiller, Baseball Digest, December 1988] *[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1119666/index.htm Rick Reuschel in Sports Illustrated, July 15, 1985] *[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1068564/index.htm Rick Reuschel in Sports Illustrated, July 10, 1989] {{s-start}} {{succession box | before = [[JoaquÃ­n AndÃºjar]] | title = [[The Sporting News Comeback Player of the Year Award|NL Comeback Player of the Year]]| years = [[1985]]| after = [[Ray Knight]]}} {{succession box | before = [[JoaquÃ­n AndÃºjar]]
